messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 63 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Modern Lower Bound Techniques in Database Theory and Constraint Satisfaction

Paper Abstract: Abstract. Conditional lower bounds based on P‚â†NPPNP\textup{P}\neq\textup{NP}, the Exponential-Time Hypothesis (ETH), or similar complexity assumptions can provide very useful information about what type of algorithms are likely to be possible. Ideally, such lower bounds would be able to demonstrate that the best known algorithms are essentially optimal and cannot be improved further. In this tutorial, we overview different types of lower bounds, and see how they can be applied to problems in database theory and constraint satisfaction.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 63 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 63"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Tight Hardness Results for LCS and Other Sequence Similarity Measures",
        "If the Current Clique Algorithms Are Optimal, so Is Valiant‚Äôs Parser",
        "More consequences of falsifying SETH and the orthogonal vectors conjecture",
        "Popular Conjectures Imply Strong Lower Bounds for Dynamic Problems",
        "Matching Triangles and Basing Hardness on an Extremely Popular Conjecture",
        "A Refined Laser Method and Faster Matrix Multiplication",
        "Finding and Counting Given Length Cycles",
        "Computational Complexity - A Modern Approach",
        "Size Bounds and Query Plans for Relational Joins",
        "Graph isomorphism in quasipolynomial time [extended abstract]",
        "Canonical Labeling of Graphs",
        "Edit Distance Cannot Be Computed in Strongly Subquadratic Time (Unless SETH is False)",
        "On Acyclic Conjunctive Queries and Constant Delay Enumeration",
        "On Non-serial Dynamic Programming",
        "Optimal Dynamic Program for r-Domination Problems over Tree Decompositions",
        "De la pertinence de l‚Äô√©num√©ration : complexit√© en logiques propositionnelle et du premier ordre. (The relevance of the list: propositional logic and complexity of the first order)",
        "Why Walking the Dog Takes Time: Frechet Distance Has No Strongly Subquadratic Algorithms Unless SETH Fails",
        "Tree Edit Distance Cannot be Computed in Strongly Subcubic Time (unless APSP can)",
        "Quadratic Conditional Lower Bounds for String Problems and Dynamic Time Warping",
        "Multivariate Fine-Grained Complexity of Longest Common Subsequence",
        "A Dichotomy Theorem for Nonuniform CSPs",
        "Linear FPT reductions and computational lower bounds",
        "Vertex cover: further observations and further improvements",
        "Some intersection theorems for ordered sets and graphs",
        "Almost Tight Lower Bounds for Hard Cutting Problems in Embedded Graphs",
        "The Complexity of Theorem-Proving Procedures",
        "Tight conditional lower bounds for counting perfect matchings on graphs of bounded treewidth, cliquewidth, and genus",
        "On Problems as Hard as CNF-SAT",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Solving Connectivity Problems Parameterized by Treewidth in Single Exponential Time",
        "Parameterized Complexity",
        "Fundamentals of Parameterized Complexity",
        "Finding List Homomorphisms from Bounded-treewidth Graphs to Reflexive Graphs: a Complete Complexity Characterization",
        "On the complexity of fixed parameter clique and dominating set",
        "The computational structure of monotone monadic SNP and constraint satisfaction: a study through Datalog and group theory",
        "Parameterized Complexity Theory",
        "Complexity of K-Tree Structured Constraint Satisfaction Problems",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "The complexity of homomorphism and constraint satisfaction problems seen from the other side",
        "When is the evaluation of conjunctive queries tractable?",
        "S-functions for graphs",
        "3-SAT Faster and Simpler ‚Äî Unique-SAT Bounds for PPSZ Hold in General",
        "On the Complexity of kùëòk-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "On the Equivalence among Problems of Bounded Width",
        "Fine-Grained Parameterized Complexity Analysis of Graph Coloring Problems",
        "Reducibility Among Combinatorial Problems",
        "On the Structure of Polynomial Time Reducibility",
        "A rigorous time bound for factoring integers",
        "Tight Hardness for Shortest Cycles and Paths in Sparse Graphs",
        "Known Algorithms on Graphs of Bounded Treewidth Are Probably Optimal",
        "Can You Beat Treewidth?",
        "On the complexity of the subgraph problem",
        "Worst-case Optimal Join Algorithms",
        "Computational Complexity",
        "On the Possibility of Faster SAT Algorithms",
        "Graph minors. III. Planar tree-width",
        "Fast approximation algorithms for the diameter and radius of sparse graphs",
        "The Complexity of Satisfiability Problems",
        "General Context-Free Recognition in Less than Cubic Time",
        "Triejoin: A Simple, Worst-Case Optimal Join Algorithm",
        "Hardness of Easy Problems: Basing Hardness on Popular Conjectures such as the Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis",
        "A Proof of CSP Dichotomy Conjecture"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 63 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Modern Lower Bound Techniques in Database Theory and Constraint Satisfaction, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
